name: Goan Fish Curry
history: Originating from Goa, a coastal state in India, Goan Fish Curry is a staple in Goan cuisine. It reflects the region's rich seafood tradition, influenced by Portuguese and local Indian flavors.
description: Goan Fish Curry is a spicy and tangy dish made with fish cooked in a coconut milk-based curry. The curry is flavored with tamarind, spices, and a paste of coconut and chilies, offering a perfect balance of heat and sourness.

ingredients.item: firm white fish (like cod or tilapia), cut into pieces

instructions.title: Prepare the Spice Paste
instructions.description: Grind grated coconut, green chilies, coriander seeds, cumin seeds, garlic, and ginger with a little water to make a smooth paste.

instructions.title: Cook the Onions
instructions.description: Heat oil in a pot. Add onions and cook until translucent.

instructions.title: Add the Spice Paste
instructions.description: Add the prepared spice paste to the onions, along with turmeric powder. Cook until the oil begins to separate.

instructions.title: Simmer with Coconut Milk and Tamarind
instructions.description: Add coconut milk, tamarind paste, and salt. Bring to a simmer.

instructions.title: Cook the Fish
instructions.description: Add the fish pieces and cook gently until the fish is done.

instructions.title: Garnish and Serve
instructions.description: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice.

tips: Use fresh, firm white fish for the best texture.
Adjust the amount of tamarind and green chilies to suit your taste.
variations: Add a few curry leaves during cooking for an authentic South Indian flavor.
Substitute fish with shrimp or other seafood for a different take on the recipe.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh, but can be refrigerated for up to 1 day.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat gently on the stove until warm.
presentationTips: Serve in a traditional earthenware bowl for a rustic feel.
Accompany with steamed basmati rice and a wedge of lime.
